blocks.title: Participant Consent Form </br></br>
blocks.ask:
Title of this Study:The Role of Cartographic Interface Complexity on Spatial Decision-Making

Principle Investigator:
Robert E. Roth, PhD
375 Science Hall
N. Park Street
Madison, WI 53706
Email: reroth@wisc.edu

Student Researcher:
Kristen Vincent
Email: kvincent2@wisc.edu

DESCRIPTION OF RESEARCH:
You are invited to participate in a study researching the design and use of interactive, web-based maps. This project is investigating interface complexity of interactive maps for spatial decision-making about the North American hazardous waste trade.

WHAT WILL MY PARTICIPATION INVOLVE?
If you choose to participate, you will be asked to complete a map-based survey about the North American hazardous waste trade. The survey should take 30-60 minutes.

ARE THERE ANY RISKS TO ME?
Risks of participation are minimal. You will be asked to provide background information, but no personally identifying information will be requested.

ARE THERE ANY BENEFITS TO ME?
There are no direct benefits for participating.

WILL I BE COMPENSATED FOR MY TIME?
You will receive $5 upon completion of the map survey.

HOW WILL MY CONFIDENTIALITY BE PROTECTED?
If you agree to participate, any personally identifying information will not be used in any publications of this work. All responses will be stored on a secure computer.

WHOM SHOULD I CONTACT IF I HAVE QUESTIONS?
You may ask any questions about the research at any time. Please contact Kristen Vincent at kvincent2@wisc.edu with any questions.

If you are not satisfied with the response of the research team, have more questions, or want to talk with someone about your rights as a research participant, you should contact the University of Wisconsin-Madison Education Research and Social & Behavioral Science IRB Office at 608-263-2320.

Your participation is completely voluntary. If you decide not to participate or to withdraw from the study, it will have no effect on you.

By selecting 'Next' below, you indicate that you have read through this consent form, had the opportunity to ask questions about your participation, and you agree to participate.

If you agree to participate in this research study, select 'Next' below, otherwise, close your browser to exit:

Thank you for agreeing to participate!

Digital interactive maps are part of our everyday lives: we navigate with them on our smartphones, they enhance the stories in popular media outlets, the run viral across our social media pages. This research seeks to explore the impact the interface has on users performing a decision-making task. Specifically, we are interested in the effects of changing the complexity of the map interface. Further, spatial decisions are complex problems and interactive maps can help users make informed decisions. Hazardous waste flows among Canada, Mexico, and the United States daily, with many management decisions needed to ensure safe transport and disposal. In this study, you will be asked to perform a decision task about the hazardous waste trade using an interactive map.

INSTRUCTIONS:

In the map survey, you will be asked to complete two ranking tasks with a series of benchmark questions in between. After each map, you will be asked your confidence in your answer and how difficult you felt the task was.

Before your task begins, you will be given an example map to work with. After your decision tasks are completed, you will be asked a series of background questions. You will be compensated after you complete the the map task and submit your survey.

ELIGIBILITY:

Before beginning, please once again review your eligibility for participating in the study. These restrictions greatly impact your responses:
  • You must be 18 years of age or older.
  • English must be your first language.
  • You must currently be living in the United States.
  • You must complete the survey on a laptop or desktop computer (i.e. not mobile).


Select 'Next' to confirm that you have read the instructions and confirm that you are eligible and ready to go to an example.

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
This is an example of what a map could look like. It shows the total amount of waste imported by each site from 2009-2012, but always review the legend carefully so you know what you are looking at. Each map that you will be shown will as a different question at a different location.

The maps will allow you to pan, or move around the map, zoom, or change the level of detail you are looking at, and retrieve details by clicking. Exploration is encouraged.

Use the map to answer the following example question.

REMEMBER: Once you select 'Next' the survey will begin and a timer will start.
Rank the sites that imported the most hazardous waste from highest to lowest:

blocks.title: Example Map
blocks.ask:
This is an example of what a map could look like. It shows the total amount of waste imported by each site from 2009-2012, but always review the legend carefully so you know what you are looking at. Each map that you will be shown will as a different question at a different location.

The maps will allow you to pan, or move around the map, zoom, or change the level of detail you are looking at, retrieve details by clicking, overlay to add additional layers, and filter information. Exploration is encouraged.

Use the map to answer the following example question.

REMEMBER: Once you select 'Next' the survey will begin and a timer will start.
Rank the sites that imported the most hazardous waste from highest to lowest:

blocks.title: Benchmark Tasks
blocks.ask: Which town had more tweets?
Which town had the most tweets?
Which county had more tweets?
Which county had the most tweets?

blocks.title: *These Questions are NOT timed.
blocks.ask: 1. On a scale of 1-5, how confident are you in your answer?
2. On a scale of 1-5, how easy was it to arrive at this answer

blocks.title: Map 1
blocks.ask: You are the manager of a newly opened Canadian firm looking to ship hazardous waste to Ohio (also Texas) to be processed. The transnational shipment is due to economic benefits and processing needs. Your waste needs to be incinerated (filter), which limits the facilities you can send to. Your goal is to send the waste to a place you know will handle (retrieve compliance data) the waste properly, otherwise your business could face scrutiny. Further, you are concerned about the communities that process waste, given recent news coverage about environmental (in)justice (overlay demographics) concerns in communities that have hazardous waste facilities. Given this, rank the top 3 sites that would be good to do business with.

blocks.title: Map 2
blocks.ask: You are a regulator at the EPA. Because of the region you work in, you are responsible for making sure all waste facilities in Ohio (also Texas) follow government regulations properly. Your task for the week is to focus on facilities that incinerate (filter) hazardous waste, which limits the facilities you work with for the week, because there is indication that some of these facilities are underperforming. Your job is to examine previous reports (retrieve compliance data) to understand each company’s past compliance record, as well as examine public concerns about the facilities in their respective communities. Recently, community members have come forward indicating they feel like they are burdened by the facility (overlay demographics). After your examination, rank the top 3 sites that need to be monitored more closely.

blocks.title: Map 3
blocks.ask: You plan to buy a new house in your home state of Ohio (also Texas). This state is home to multiple hazardous waste facilities, which causes concern for you and your family. Particularly, facilities with incinerators (filter) cause concern because of emissions from the incineration process. As you decide which city and neighborhood to live in, you investigate the hazardous waste facilities and see which ones have a record of processing waste properly (retrieve compliance data). Further, you examine the communities that have these waste facilities because of recent news coverage about environmental (in)justice (overlay demographics) concerns in communities that have hazardous waste facilities. Given this, rank the top 3 sites that you would not want to live nearby.

blocks.title:
*The survey is no longer being timed.

Exit Survey-North American Hazardous Waste Trade
blocks.ask: Please rank how difficult it was to understand the hazardous waste trade topic:
Discuss which points were confusing, if any:
Please describe your decision-making process:
What information about the hazardous waste trade would have made coming to your decisions easier?
What are your views of the hazardous waste trade?
Should we trade hazardous waste?

blocks.title: Exit Survey-Interactive Maps
blocks.ask: Please rank how difficult it was to understand the map:
Discuss which points were confusing, if any:
Changing which features on the map would have made coming to your decisions easier?

blocks.title: Exit Survey-Background Information
blocks.ask: What is your age?
What is your gender?
What state do you currently live in?
Have you ever lived in Texas or Ohio?
What is the highest degree you have received?
What field is your degree(s) in?
How much experience do you have with maps?
How much experience do you have with the hazardous waste industry?
How familiar are you with maps?
How familiar are you with online, interactive maps (i.e. Google Maps)?
How familiar are you with the hazardous waste trade?
How often do you use computers?
What device did you complete this survey on?
What best describes the manner you interacted with the map and submitted your survey responses?

blocks.title: Thank you!
blocks.ask: Thank you for taking the time to complete this survey. Your response has been recorded. You will receive your payment shortly.</br></br>Please close your browser to exit.
